title: Ed Yong on Breaking Down and Putting Yourself Back Together
content:
My favorite presentation at XOXO this year was Ed Yongâ€™s talk about the pandemic, journalism, his work over the past four years, and the personal toll that all those things took on him. I just watched the entire thing again, riveted the whole time.

Hearing how thoughtfully & compassionately he approached his work during the pandemic was really inspirational: â€œMy pillars are empathy, curiosity, and kindness â€” and much else flows from that.â€ And his defense of journalism, especially journalism as â€œa caretaking professionâ€:

For people who feel lost and alone, we get to say through our work: you are not. For people who feel like society has abandoned them and their lives do not matter, we get to say: actually, they fucking do. We are one of the only professions that can do that through our work and that can do that at scale â€” a scale commensurate with many of the crises that we face.

Then, it was hard to hear about how his work â€œcompletely brokeâ€ him. To say that Yongâ€™s experience mirrored my own is, according to the mild PTSD Iâ€™m experiencing as I consider everything he related in that video, is an understatement. We covered the pandemic in different ways, but like Yong, I was completely consumed by it. I read hundreds(/thousands?) of stories, papers, and posts a week for more than a year, wrote hundreds of posts, and posted hundreds of links, trying to make sense of what was happening so that, hopefully, I could help others do the same. The sense of purpose and duty I felt to my readers â€” and to reality â€” was intense, to the point of overwhelm.

Like Yong, I eventually had to step back, taking a seven-month sabbatical in 2022. I didnâ€™t talk about the pandemic at all in that post, but in retrospect, it was the catalyst for my break. Unlike Yong, I am back at it: hopefully more aware of my limits, running like itâ€™s an ultramarathon rather than a sprint, trying to keep my empathy for others in the right frame so I can share their stories effectively without losing myself.1

I didnâ€™t get a chance to meet Yong in person at XOXO, so: Ed, thank you so much for all of your marvelous work and amazing talk and for setting an example of how to do compassionate, important work without compromising your values. (And I love seeing your bird photos pop up on Bluesky.)
